subject: Re: [junit] All Methods Public
msgSnippet: Well, I started using the Class + ClassHelper Pattern in all of my projects now and I m really starting to dig it. Some of us said that we could wait and see
messageBody:
Well,

I started using the Class + ClassHelper "Pattern" in
all of my projects now and I'm really starting to dig
it.

Some of us said that we could wait and see which
methods are tricky enough to require moving to a
helper and testing there, but sometimes I start off
with a simple method and then it gets tricky later
on...then I have to refactor. Now it's on the helper,
so I'm good to go.

Also, since the method is not public, we might say
"We'll just say that this is simple enough, and not
test it", which if there's a large team of developers,
unit testing is left up in the air. Some developers
may put the simplex algorithm inside a single private
method, and say "Well, it's simple", no need to test
that. Thus skipping the benefits of test driven
development in simplifying the design into small
testable pieces.


Others said it might lead to increased coupling. But
the only coupling in the Class + ClassHelper pattern
is the coupling between ClassA and the ClassAHelper.
If ClassB uses ClassAHelper, then the pattern is
broken.
The proper way to do it, would be to move the ClassA
method that class be wants into a Utility library.

Hence, it makes it really easy to see which methods
should be moved into general utility libraries for
reuse, that can be contributed to commons-lang or
commons-io, or some other apache commons library later
on.

It also makes it easy to look for utility library
methods that could be substituted, when possible.

Lastly, everything can be tested, making it easier to
incorporate automatic test generation later.

So it could be that the code is smeeeelllleee, but I
still dig it!!

Cheers,
- Ole
